content.intro:
Straddling East and West, between sea and mountain, past and present, luxury and reconstruction, Beirut is a city where opposite realities live in a completely unique harmony. It is a city full of life in a country several thousand years old.

Dynamic, cosmopolitan, noisy, chaotic, but also enchanting and inviting, Beirut vibrates to its own unique rhythm, while at the same time resonating to the chant of the muezzin, the peal of church bells, and the constant din of car horns. It is a city that awakens passions, evokes dreams, and defies all indifference. For a fascinating insight into its history, visit Martyrs' Square, in the heart of old Beirut, recently rebuilt stone by stone. In many neighbourhoods, the Maronite church (Catholic) is next to the Orthodox church, which is next to the mosque. In the eastern part of the city, markets are side by side with luxury boutiques, bazaars pop up at the foot of palaces redolent of hookah smoke and the smell of the jasmine that hangs from balconies. Walking through suburbs still marked by war, one is surprised to see historical monuments like the National Museum of Beirut, the Sursock Museum, the American University, and the Clock Tower surrounded by new luxury stores, art galleries, and trendy restaurants. And no trip to Beirut is complete without a stroll along the Beirut Corniche to the Pigeon Rocks, two sentinels rising out of the sea at the westernmost tip of the city.

In Beirut, dining is a moveable feast of fragrant dishes, falafel, Turkish delight, white coffee, and mezze. Cooking is an art, but above all a way of life. And after years of conflict and instability, Beirut has once again become a temple of nightlife, on par with New York and London. You'll find the most high-spirited places in the neighbourhood of Gemmayzé. Don't leave the country without discovering Byblos, with its historic harbour and charming old town, and the exceptional archaeological sites in Tyre.

content.title: Contemporary hedonism at Kaléo

introduction.small: In Beirut's city centre near the marina, Kaléo advocates Western Europe influences in the kitchen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Contemporary hedonism at Kaléo

paragraphs.text:
Beirut has built a reputation of design capital for the Middle-East. Each new restaurant opening is therefore carefully conceived as being part of a larger urban landscape. Located downtown, Kaléo continues the trend with its arty atmosphere. The restaurant showcases a colourful and whimsical setting, with prominence given to cosmic patterns that seem to come straight from Miró's surrealist imagination. Paying tribute to Lebanese heritage, a few elements scattered here and there strongly hark back to the architecture of Byblos' churches. The compendium makes for a contemporary and casual decor, foreshadowing the contents of your plate. The menu offers Europe-inspired dishes, and you would gladly indulge in a grouper carpaccio topped with a few lemon drops, oil, spices and edible flowers. The grilled eggplant and miso sauce is another refined gastronomical proposition for the epicurean in you.

Kaléo
Dr. Fawzi Daouk Street

Mina el Hosn
Beirut

content.title: Pacifico, nightlife pioneer in Beirut

introduction.small: An institution of the Monot Street opened in the 1990s, Pacifico remains just as popular, for both cocktails and a Latino atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pacifico, nightlife pioneer in Beirut

paragraphs.text:
Former prerequisite location for night owls in the capital, Monot Street has seen festive spots progressively close in favour of other neighbourhoods. And yet, Pacifico, emblem of the glory days, remains just as attractive as it was. A pioneer of Lebanese nightlife in the late 20th century, this Mexican bar is definitely a must in the Achrafieh district. With bright red and pale yellow walls, wooden fans and South American decoration, it won its reputation through the quality of its cocktails. The very large drink menu will please everybody, especially with the signature Margarita. Even non-alcoholic drinks show some originality: putting revisited classics aside, order a Rising Sun (cranberry and apple juices, lime, ginger and soda water) or a Leo's (orange juice, lime, homemade grenadine, almond syrup and soda water). Add a few Latin-Caribbean tapas and you will be ready for the sweetness of Beirut nights, amid a lush and green garden.

Pacifico
Monot Street
Beirut

www.pacifico.mapforfood.com

Menu: cocktails from 15,000 LBP

content.title: Meet the Roman gods at the ruins of Baalbek

introduction.small: Jupiter, Venus, Mercury and Bacchus were once celebrated here. Today, the great Greco-Roman temples are only ruins, which testify however to the splendour of the past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Meet the Roman gods at the ruins of Baalbek

paragraphs.text:
Just 90 kilometres from Beirut stand the ruins of the Phoenician city of Baalbek, formerly called ‘Heliopolis' or ‘city of the sun'. Listed as a World Heritage site by UNESCO, these Greco-Roman temples were erected in honour of Jupiter, Venus, Bacchus and Mercury and are among the largest ever built.

As you walk along, you will feel the weight of history, of the people who worshiped their gods in these places until they left these monuments fall to ruin over the years.

Admire the temple of Bacchus, the best preserved site, which contains remains of Bacchic sculptures—the one dedicated to Venus, which is distinguished by its circular shape, is the smallest. Finally, the sanctuary of Jupiter is the largest with its imposing columns more than twenty meters high—they seem to reach up and touch the sky.

Baalbek Ruins
Baalbek

content.title: Al-Sultan Brahim, a family affair

introduction.small: A Lebanese restaurant that has made seafood its specialty, Al-Sultan Brahim is a must in the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Al-Sultan Brahim, a family affair

paragraphs.text:
Since 1961, Al-Sultan Brahim has been a family affair, born of the passion of siblings and voted ‘Best Quality Restaurant in the Arab world' in 2016. Having wandered all morning and unearthed treasures of all kinds have lunch in this institution just steps from the souks of Beirut. Seafood is their specialty and since the establishment is close to the port, you are assured of the freshness of your meal. For a starter, opt for the aubergine grilled with tahini, before continuing with grilled octopus marinated in the special Al-Sultan Brahim sauce or Gambas al ajillo—spicy shrimp sautéed with lemon juice.

You will enjoy a very pleasant lunch bathed in light near the immense picture windows or on the covered terrace, where you can hear the gentle lapping of the sea and feel refreshed by the breeze.

Al-Sultan Brahim
Beirut Souks
Downtown
Beirut

www.al-sultanbrahim.com

content.title: Aïshti Foundation: culture, fashion, and lifestyle, all in one

introduction.small: Designed by British architect David Adjaye, the foundation is part of Aïshti By The Sea, an ambitious complex bringing together fashion, art, and commerce.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aïshti Foundation: culture, fashion, and lifestyle, all in one

paragraphs.text:
The Aïshti By The Sea commercial complex is gargantuan: 35,000 square metres of buildings facing the sea, with more than 80 luxury boutiques, restaurants, a spa, bars, and an art foundation.

In 15 years, the Lebanese businessman and collector Tony Salamé, CEO of Aïshti, has assembled more than 2,500 works by Lucio Fontana, Giuseppe Penone, Tony Cragg, Julian Schnabel, Enrico Castellani, and many more, all of which are displayed in this foundation, inaugurated in October 2015, in Jal el Dib, near Beirut.

Even the temporary exhibitions present works drawn from Salamé's impressive personal collection.

Fondation Aïshti
71 rue El Moutrane

content.title: Le Gray: hotel and restaurants for all tastes

introduction.small: This high-end hotel at the foot of Martyrs Square in the city centre is part of the London-based chain of Gordon Campbell hotels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Gray: hotel and restaurants for all tastes

paragraphs.text:
Le Gray is located in the Central District, close to many historic sites, including the Great Mosque. The 87 rooms and suites are nicely decorated in 1980s style, and there are nearly 500 works of contemporary art throughout the premises.

The advantage of this address lies mainly in its different restaurants. Gordon's Café in the garden serves light dishes and salads; if you prefer something more chic, the Indigo has stunning 180° views and the best beef in town.

Cherry, with its lounge atmosphere and many cocktails, is ideal for early evening. Cigar lovers should head straight to the Cigar Lounge.

Le Gray
Martyrs Square
Central District
Beirut

+961 (0)1 97 11 11

www.campbellgrayhotels.com/le-gray/

Rooms: from 300 USD

content.title: The Corniche and Pigeon Rocks: a walk along the Mediterranean

introduction.small: Drink coffee, get your shoes shined, go for a stroll—the Corniche is the active core of Beirut culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Corniche and Pigeon Rocks: a walk along the Mediterranean

paragraphs.text:
The Beirut Corniche is one of the world's most attractive and popular seaside promenades. With friends or on your own, the stroll between Saint George Bay in the north to Avenue General de Gaulle in the south, past joggers, beach bars, private beaches, and shoeshine boys, is always a delight.

On one side is the Mediterranean Sea, and on the other modern buildings and hotels. Stop to admire the Pigeon Rocks, the symbol of the city, two limestone cliffs 46-metres high, which you can climb to take in spectacular views of the city and the sea.

During your walk, be sure to stop at Raouda a café the locals call ‘Shatila' to read the L'Orient-Le Jour, one of the main Lebanese dailies.

content.title: Beirut National Museum: the most beautiful archaeology museum in the Middle East

introduction.small: Archaeological artefacts representing 7,000 years of Lebanese history, housed in a colonial-style building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beirut National Museum: the most beautiful archaeology museum in the Middle East

paragraphs.text:
After the war, in 1997, one of the government's top priorities was to very quickly create a prestigious showcase for the 100,000 archaeological treasures discovered during excavations.

More than 1,300 objects are on display in this human-scaled building, tracing chronologically the history of the region. The sarcophagus of Ahiram, King of Byblos in the 13th century BC with its sentence in Phoenician considered to be one of the oldest writings in the world is among the collection's most prized pieces. The ground floor has sarcophagi, mosaics, statues, and bas-reliefs from the first and second millennia BC and the Roman Byzantine period.

The second floor has objects from prehistory to the Hellenistic and Roman times.

Beirut National Museum
Museum Street
Beirut

+961 (0)1 426 703

content.title: La Centrale: a spectacular setting, with top-notch French cuisine

introduction.small: Designed by architect Bernard Khoury, La Centrale is a futuristic backdrop for your Beirut nights.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Centrale: a spectacular setting, with top-notch French cuisine

paragraphs.text:
This restaurant is the go-to bar in Beirut. Opened in 2001 in a traditional house from the early 20th century, the venue fulfils architect Bernard Khoury's wish to make a grand impression hence the vast central hall with its 11 metre wine cellar tower.

The food is French with a Mediterranean influence: scallops with lemon, sea bream baked in salt, roast bar with ginger, or farm chicken with tarragon. Take the elevator, a tube of steel and glass, to the terrace bar for a cocktail, accompanied, if you're still hungry, with a quinoa salad.The view is gorgeous.

La Centrale
Mar Maroun Street
Beirut

+961 3 915 925

www.centrale-restaurant.com

Menu: around 75 USD

content.title: Chouf and its villages: an exceptional natural heritage

introduction.small: After visiting the Chouf-district villages of Deir el Kamar and Beiteddine, venture out with a guide to the Al Shouf Cedar Nature Reserve.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chouf and its villages: an exceptional natural heritage

paragraphs.text:
Chouf is a 500 square kilometre mountainous region 40 kilometres southeast of Beirut. It is home to the largest concentration of cedar trees in the Middle East, some of which are thousands of years old, including one that recently celebrated its 4,000th birthday.

The Al Shouf Cedar Nature Reserve hosts 200 hundred varieties of bird, 32 species of wild mammals, and 500 species of plants. It is a fabulous hiking destination: you start at 1,650 metres at Misyaf al Mir and admire a breath-taking panorama.

Don't miss the Maronite town of Beiteddine and the palace of the Emir Bashir: built in the 19th century, in ochre-coloured stones, it is now the summer residence of Lebanese presidents. Another must is Deir el Kamar ‘the convent of the moon' a Christian village with cobbled streets. The convent there is exceptional, as is the famous Saïdet church.

+961 53 50 250

www.shoufcedar.org

content.title: Beirut Art Center: the heart of contemporary art in Lebanon

introduction.small: A private initiative to showcase contemporary art and the local art scene.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beirut Art Center: the heart of contemporary art in Lebanon

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 2009 on two floors in a former industrial furniture building, the 1,500-square-metre BAC is the private initiative of former gallery owner Sandra Dagher and Lebanese artist Lamia Joreige, who've sought to provide Beirut with a reference centre for contemporary art.

As the Lebanese state has totally divested itself of any mandate to support culture, the BAC helps to sustain the local art scene. The centre does not have its own collection, but it does put on temporary exhibitions.

It also has concerts and theatre performances, but, above all, through its BAC design program, it tries to promote products conceived of and made by local designers.

Beirut Art Center
Jisr El Wati - Off Corniche an Nahr. Building 13
Beirut

+961 (0)1 39 70 18

www.beirutartcenter.org

content.title: Jeita Grotto: natural wonder of humanity

introduction.small: Located 18 kilometres north of Beirut, the gigantic Jeita Grotto's interconnected caves are among the most impressive in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jeita Grotto: natural wonder of humanity

paragraphs.text:
Located in Nahr al-Kalb, about 350 metres above sea level in a wide green valley, these vestiges of prehistory are an absolutely unique spectacle. The waterfalls and air currents cause a deafening noise, hence the name Jeita means ‘roar'. The caves, reachable partly on foot and partly by boat, consist of two distinct sections.

Discovered in 1958 by a Lebanese team of speleologists, the upper part, called the ‘dry galleries' are visited on foot. An access tunnel 120 metres long immerses you in a lunar theatre of monumental arches and stalagmites.

The lower part, discovered in 1836, is accessed by canoe along the same underground river that provides drinking water for Beirut. In winter, the lower part is closed.

Jeïta Grotto
Qornet El Hamra
Valley of the Dog River
Keserwan
Beyrouth

+961 9 220 841

www.jeitagrotto.com

content.title: L'Albergo: Oriental charm and luxury

introduction.small: In the heart of the Achrafieh district, this mini-palace comprises nine floors in an early 20th century building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Albergo: Oriental charm and luxury

paragraphs.text:
Hotel Albergo Beyrouth is the only Relais & Châteaux hotel in Lebanon. Located in the residential and bourgeois district of Ashrafieh, its décor is a mix of Art Deco and Ottoman.

The lobby by French interior designer Jacques Garcia is a triumph of shimmering colours and fabrics. Each of the 33 suites is different, with antique furniture, paintings, and Aubusson tapestries carefully chosen by Tarfa Salam. Upon arrival, a carafe of homemade lemonade awaits you in your room. You can then relax in a beautiful lounge-library and consult books on Lebanese art.

The top floor restaurant has a marvellous view over the rooftops of the city and excellent Italian Lebanese cuisine.

Hotel Albergo Beyrouth
137 rue Abdel Wahab El Inglizi
Beirut

+961 (0)1 33 97 97

www.albergobeirut.com

Rooms: from 280 USD

content.title: Tawlet: celebrating Lebanese culture through its cooking

introduction.small: Tawlet means ‘table'—the central focus of Kamal Mouzawak's project is to welcome people to his table with a global project combining cuisine and social business.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tawlet: celebrating Lebanese culture through its cooking

paragraphs.text:
The project of Kamal Mouzawak began in 2004 with the opening of a farmer's market in the Souk el Tayeb to promote local farmers. In 2009, he opened this ‘table' in the heart of the souk to showcase Lebanese home cooking, because, according to Kamal, ‘food is always a story'.

Located at the end of an alley between apartment buildings with laundry drying on their balconies, each day a different cook provides a different take on Lebanese history and culture through its food.

Tawlet is a social enterprise business, as all proceeds are reinvested to support social projects with organic farmers and cooks from the region. It is a magnificent achievement.

Tawlet
12 rue Naher
Beirut

+961 (0)1 44 81 29

www.soukeltayeb.com/tawlet/beirut/shou-tabkha-el-mama-lyom/

Menu: around 25 USD

content.title: Villa Clara: a unique hotel experience

introduction.small: A charming boutique hotel in a revamped 1920s private house in the fashionable Mar Mkhayel neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Clara: a unique hotel experience

paragraphs.text:
The blue colour of the facade puts you immediately in a romantic and serene mood. The restaurant on the ground floor overlooks a beautiful garden surrounded by trees, with a play area for children and a petanque court.

Chef Olivier Gougeon serves delicious French cuisine, and the wine list is superb. Upstairs, fall under the spell of the monumental Murano chandelier, the Andrée Putman furniture, and the seven guest rooms, all individually decorated with antique furniture, 1920s paintings, hand-painted silk wallpaper, and floor mosaics.

Villa Clara
Rue Kenchaara
Ashrafieh
Mar Mkhayel
Beyrouth

villaclara.fr

content.title: Sursock Museum: a fully renovated showcase of Lebanese art

introduction.small: In the middle-class neighbourhood of Achrafieh, this newly refurbished 1912 building shines a light on the city's history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sursock Museum: a fully renovated showcase of Lebanese art

paragraphs.text:
The Sursock Museum was reopened in October 2015, after a renovation of the building and gardens by Willmotte & Associés.

The neo-Moorish architecture of the museum has been retained, but a new basement has been dug out to accommodate an auditorium, library, and further exhibition spaces. The 8,500-square-metre museum was bequeathed by the businessman Nicolas Ibrahim Sursock, in 1951, to showcase local and international artists.

Among the many Lebanese artists represented in the museum's 5,000-work collection are Shafic Abboud, Etel Adnan, Assadour, Daoud Corm and Paul Guiragossian.

Sursock Museum
Greek Orthodox Archbishopric Street
Ashrafieh 2071 5509
Beirut

+961 (0)1 20 20 01

content.title: Tyre: the great ancient city

introduction.small: The amazing Roman ruins in Tyre, just 83 km south of Beirut, are well worth the drive. As are the beaches!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tyre: the great ancient city

paragraphs.text:
The two archaeological sites in the ancient city of Tyre, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, are spectacular.

An arena, spas, and the palaestra the wrestling school are in the first. In the second is a magnificent Roman-Byzantine necropolis, with many sarcophagi, funerary buildings and enclosures, and chapels. The monumental arch is impressive, as is 2nd-century racetrack one of the biggest in the Roman world, it could hold up to 20,000 people, and it now hosts a summer music festival.

Tyre is also home to eight kilometres of beaches with crystal clear water, making this one of the most beautiful stretches of seaside in the country.

content.title: Liza : superb dining in the heart of Ashrafieh

introduction.small: Liza and Ziad Asseily have opened several locations in Lebanon and Paris.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Liza : superb dining in the heart of Ashrafieh

paragraphs.text:
Liza occupies 500 square metres on the first floor of the Metropolitan Club, and consists of a vast central lounge plus a series of large rooms with seven-metre-high ceilings.

All areas of the restaurant have been enhanced by the work of various contemporary artists: the Italian Idarica Gazzoni for the banana leaf wallpaper; Tom Dixon for the bar; Maria Ousseimi and Ginette Gemmayze for the overall design; and Rasha Nawam for the accessories.

The food is excellent: Lebanese cuisine with a light modern touch.

Liza
Doumani
Beirut

+961 (0)1 20 81 08

www.lizabeirut.com

Menu: around 20 USD

content.title: The Four Seasons: stunning sea views

introduction.small: If you're looking for comfort and excellence in every detail—and a room with a sea view—the Four Seasons is for you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Four Seasons: stunning sea views

paragraphs.text:
An ultramodern building with soft, rounded lines on 26 floors, the Four Seasons has all the benefits and amenities you'd expect to find in this type of facility, plus the ever present smile of Stefan Simkovics, the hotel's friendly owner.

There now ned French designer Pierre Yves Rouchon has given the 230 rooms and suites a new, very contemporary look, with a few oriental touches in the fabulous golden wallpaper, for example.

The gorgeous Rooftop Pool Lounge and the spa facility on the top floor overlook the sea, within earshot of the constant, lulling lap of the waves below.

Four Seasons
1418 Prof. Wafic Sinno Avenue
Minet El Hosn
Beirut

+961 (0)1 76 10 00

www.fourseasons.com/beirut

content.title: Bouyouti: the best way to discover Lebanon

introduction.small: In the heart of the Chouf region, 45 kilometres from Beirut, Bouyouti is a haven of peace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bouyouti: the best way to discover Lebanon

paragraphs.text:
In this house originally destined for family and friends bouyouti means ‘my house' Rafic Bazerji has created a spectacular launch pad for explorations of Chouf, a mountainous region in the heart of Lebanon, halfway between Deir el Kamar and Beiteddine.

Enjoy the views of the hills and surrounding nature from poolside or under the fruit trees. There are ten stonewalled cabins, each of which sleeps two to four people, all carefully decorated and furnished with well-chosen Lebanese objects and furniture.

The breakfast is a memorable showcase of local products.

Bouyouti
Maaser Beit Ed Dine
Liban

+961 (0)3 31 02 00

www.bouyouti.com

Rooms: from 200 USD

content.title: Le Petit Gris: A French bistro

introduction.small: A classic address in the Gemmayzé neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Petit Gris: A French bistro

paragraphs.text:
The red awnings on the facade of the Petit Gris give this street a nice splash of colour. The 100-square-metre restaurant is decorated with wine bottles on the walls. The cuisine is traditional bistro: steak and French fries and steak tartare, but it also offers up more unexpected dishes, like a snail casserole or eggs Mamie Manette. As it should be in a place like this, the wine list is excellent.

Le Petit Gris
Rue du Petit Collège
Saifi
Beirut

+961 (0)1 44 37 37

www.facebook.com/LePetitGris

Menu: around 40-60 USD

content.title: Byblos: more than 7,000 years of history

introduction.small: Forty kilometres north of Beirut, the Phoenician city of Byblos has played a key role in the history of mankind.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Byblos: more than 7,000 years of history

paragraphs.text:
A trip to Byblos is a trip back in time through 7,000 years of history, from the Neolithic period to ancient Egypt and the Phoenicians, and on through other cultural and religious influences Greek, Roman, Christian, and Byzantine.

In the southern part of the old town are the archaeological ruins of the temple of Ba‘alat Gebal, along with obelisks and Neolithic huts extending to the Crusader castle. A visit to the wax museum is a great way to learn, through its vast collection of tableaux, the full arc of Lebanese history and culture. Stop in the small restaurant Bab El Mina in the old port for freshly caught fish with taratour, the local sauce, before returning to the streets of the old city and its souks.

After a day visiting archaeological sites, return to the excesses of the present at the Edde Sands private beach seven restaurants, six pools, multiple shops, all on the most beautiful beach in Lebanon.

Bab El Mina
Vieux Port
Byblos

+961 (0)9 54 04 75

www.babelmina.com

content.title: Souk el Tayeb: Beirut's first farmer's market

introduction.small: Nothing better than a Saturday stroll through stalls of organic produce straight from the farm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Souk el Tayeb: Beirut's first farmer's market

paragraphs.text:
In 2004, Kamal Mouzawak organised the first farmer's market in Lebanon, exclusively for local organic and sustainable products.

Every Saturday, from 9:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m., farmers and artisans of all faiths, bring their best to the Souk el Tayeb market, which serves as a showcase of the country's multiculturalism. Druse, Shiites, Sunnis, and Christians from the coast, the mountains, the Bekaa Valley, or the outskirts of town make the weekly pilgrimage. The sight of colourful baskets and the aroma of garlic and spice are intoxicating. The selection of quality crafts on sale is impressive baskets, soaps, and embroidery, all made by local designers.

Restaurant Tawlet is the perfect spot for people watching, and the lunch is delicious.

+961 14 42 664

www.soukeltayeb.com

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Beirut
content.introduction: Beirut enjoys a Mediterranean climate with hot and humid summers, and some 300 days of sunshine every year. Winters are mild and rainy, with occasionally violent storms. In April and May, the khamsin, a strong wind from the north, coats the city with a fine layer of sand.

airports.title: Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport
airports.description:
The Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport is located about 7 kilometres (4 miles) south of the city centre.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Beirut and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the Ouzaï highway
    • Short- and long-term parking facilities are available at the airport, with a total of 2,350 spaces (LBP 8,500 for up to 1 hour, LBP 22,000 for 24 hours).
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall.
  • By bus
    • At the present time, there are no public transport services between the airport and the city centre, although a project is underway to introduce regular bus service along this route.
  • By taxi
    • Certified airport taxis, displaying the airport's logo on the side, are available at the ranks outside the arrivals hall. Their fares are regulated by the airport authorities: about LBP 25,000 for the 15-minute trip to the city centre. Standard taxis are also available, but the fare must be negotiated beforehand.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +961 (0)1 62 80 00
  • Website: www.beirutairport.gov.lb

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Beirut
transportation.description: Getting around Beirut is pleasant and easy. Taxis are plentiful, rental cars are readily available, and a large number of bus routes criss-cross the city. All these options make exploring Beirut incredibly simple.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Beirut
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Beirut each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: Third month of the Hijri calendar: Mawlid (Birth of the Prophet, national holiday)
events.description: This festival commemorates the birth of the Prophet Muhammad and is one of the most important days on the Islamic (or Hegira) calendar. Lebanese Muslims use this opportunity to recall the values advocated by the Prophet. It is also a day when families gather to share a traditional meal in a festive atmosphere.

events.title: January 6: Epiphany (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Celebrated by Christians in Lebanon, this festival commemorates the visit of the Magi to the Infant Jesus, the manifestation of the divinity of Christ at his baptism, and his first miracle at Cana. Processions are held in the Christian districts of Beirut.

events.title: Ninth month of the Hijri  calendar : Ramadan (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The Islamic holy month of Ramadan, during which the Quran was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, is an especially pious time for Muslims in Lebanon. Fasting begins each day at sunrise and ends at sunset.

events.title: First day of the tenth month of the Hijri calendar: Eid al-Fitr (national holiday)
events.description: This day marks the end of Ramadan and is a time for family celebrations by Muslims across Beirut, with exchanges of gifts, especially new clothes, and great feasts bringing together all family members. Music, dancing and street processions are also a prominent feature.

events.title: July–August: Baalbek International Festival (local event)
events.description: Less than an hour's drive from the Lebanese capital, Baalbek hosts this international festival every summer, a major event on the Lebanese cultural calendar featuring performances at the Temple of Bacchus and other venues by leading artists, in a programme ranging from classical music to theatre, dance and jazz.

events.title: August 1: Lebanese Army Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the day in 1945 when the Lebanese Armed Forces were placed under the full authority of the national government, two years after Lebanon gained independence from French rule. Celebrations begin with official ceremonies and military parades early in the day and continue into the evening with concerts and fireworks in various districts throughout the city.

events.title: Last month of the Hijiri calendar: Eid al-Adha (national)
events.description: It is considered the most important of the yearly Muslim holidays and honours Ibrahim as a model for all believers. This is also an occasion for sumptuous family gatherings, for which it is recommended to multiply offerings and gifts.

events.title: November 22: Independence Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the end of the French mandate over Lebanon in 1943, after 23 years of colonial rule. It also honours the unwritten power-sharing arrangement between Lebanese Christians and Muslims known as the National Pact (al-Mithaq al-Watani) that laid the foundations of the Lebanese state. Festivities in Beirut include concerts and fireworks.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Lebanon
administrativeProcedures.description:
A visa is required for any French citizen entering Lebanon. A short-stay visa, for a renewable period of 30 days, will be delivered to you upon arrival. Your passport must be valid for at least six months from your date of entry. If you plan to stay for more than two months in Lebanon, you are urged to report to the Directorate of General Security before your first visa expires so as to obtain a new visa for the remainder of your stay.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Beirut and Lebanon, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. You may also follow the travel advice of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs:

http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays/liban

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Thursday from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m., Friday from 8 a.m. to 11 a.m., and Saturday from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m.

banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m., and Saturday from 8:30 a.m. to 1 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March
End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Beirut, it is customary to leave a tip at the city's hotels and restaurants. If you are satisfied with the service, an appropriate amount is between 5 and 10% of the bill.
